column4: do you think there should be more tutorials for beginners about ubuntu?
there's plenty of documentation out there
help.ubuntu.com
shutdown with -F
among any other options, yeah.
well, you'll need a time.
shutdown -rF now will reboot, and fsck, -hF will turn off the computer after the shutdown
just once.  it'll get removed automatically
have you looked into edubuntu's thinclient thing?
What are you trying to prevent?  Just lockdown the user to not be able to do anything.
i am trying to prevent from standalone ubuntu installs ( gnome desktop ) from being broken, and need the defaults to restore after reboot ...
from being broken: don't give the user admin powers.  As for defaults to restore, thats... well, accomplishable a number of ways.  Simply removing write permissions places is one.
if you wanted, you could also just boot from an imagine each time.  Although I'm not sure about specifics of that one
https://wiki.ubuntu.com/BootToRAM  There's one.
except I think that won't use the HDD at all, except during boot.
https://help.ubuntu.com/community/LiveCDCustomization
alromaithi, gksu nautilus, not sudo nautilus
no it doesnt.  Don't use sudo for graphical apps, it sometimes causes permission errors and stuff.
9.10 doesn't perform yet ;)
#ubuntu+1, 9.10 doesn't exist, Karmic does.
Again, #ubuntu+1 is for the development version, this channel is not.
#ubuntu-server does exist, but this channel is appropriate as well
